bibl.title: Letter from Juan Guiteras to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 19, 1908

div1.p: Guiteras disputes Gorgas' theories about immunity to yellow fever and eradication of the disease.

div1.head: Letter from Juan Guiteras to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 19, 1908

opener.unclear:
Please return
after reading
J. R. K.

div1.p:
I thank you for
sending me Gorgas' letter.

In the experiment of the two cities,
I think, to carry his point, he would
have to do stegomyia work with
a thoroughness and promptness
that has never been equalled in
the past.

Which ever one of the two methods can be
brought more promptly to the highest
degree of perfection, that will be the best,
and this must vary with the varying
circumstances. As I said in my report,
either method alone, if followed to perfection,
ought to stop yellow fever absolutely within
a month.

About the children; the burden of proof
must go to those who pretend that a disease
has become unaggressive to a certain class of the
population in some mysterious manner; for,
2
how it has happened, how they account
for it, does not appear. The burden of
proof is with them, because there is nothing
analogous in Pathology.

And what has become of the immunity
of creole children in New Orleans, and Mobile
and Charleston? Do you remember that
in the first half of the last century
physicians of those cities held the
same view that the Cubans have
eptkept up for a longer time. No body
there believes it now. How did it disappear?

The further back you go in the history of
these y. f. countries the more thoroughly
rooted you find this idea of immunity.
The disease was supposed to be a
climatic disease and no one could
imagine the motives liable to it. As these
races grew older in these regions the
evidences of immunity should have in-
creased; but instead of that we find
that the theory has weakened. Blair in
British Guayana was the first to
question it.

Is this defence something inherited?
Then why have we the Cubans always ad-
mitted that a Cuban born child is
liable to the disease when he leaves
the country in early life?

If you had seen an epidemic
of yellow fever in Key West! The majority
of children, (Cuban or American parentage)
were affected who were born since the year
before the last preceding epidemic.
